types.name: App
types.description: An App is the Arkitekt equivalent of a Software Application. It is a collection of `Releases` that can be all part of the same application. E.g the App `Napari` could have the releases `0.1.0` and `0.2.0`.

fields.name: identifier
fields.description: The identifier of the app. This should be a globally unique string that identifies the app. We encourage you to use the reverse domain name notation. E.g. `com.example.myapp`

fields.name: logo
fields.description: The logo of the app. This should be a url to a logo that can be used to represent the app.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the app

fields.name: releases
fields.description: The releases of the app. A release is a version of the app that can be installed by a user.

types.name: AppFilter
types.description: App(id, name, identifier, logo)

types.name: AppIdentifier
types.description: The App identifier is a unique identifier for an app. It is used to identify the app in the database and in the code. We encourage you to use the reverse domain name notation. E.g. `com.example.myapp`

types.name: Boolean
types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.

types.name: Client
types.description:
A client is a way of authenticating users with a release.
 The strategy of authentication is defined by the kind of client. And allows for different authentication flow. 
 E.g a client can be a DESKTOP app, that might be used by multiple users, or a WEBSITE that wants to connect to a user's account, 
 but also a DEVELOPMENT client that is used by a developer to test the app. The client model thinly wraps the oauth2 client model, which is used to authenticate users.

fields.name: kind
fields.description: The configuration of the client. This is the configuration that will be sent to the client. It should never contain sensitive information.

fields.name: logo
fields.description: The logo of the release. This should be a url to a logo that can be used to represent the release.

fields.name: mappings
fields.description: The mappings of the client. A mapping is a mapping of a service to a service instance. This is used to configure the composition.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the client. This is a human readable name of the client.

fields.name: oauth2Client
fields.description: The real oauth2 client that is used to authenticate users with this client.

fields.name: public
fields.description: Is this client public? If a client is public

fields.name: release
fields.description: The release that this client belongs to.

fields.name: tenant
fields.description: The user that manages this release.

fields.name: token
fields.description: The configuration of the client. This is the configuration that will be sent to the client. It should never contain sensitive information.

fields.name: user
fields.description: If the client is a DEVELOPMENT client, which requires no further authentication, this is the user that is authenticated with the client.

types.name: ClientFilter
types.description: Client(id, name, release, oauth2_client, kind, user, organization, redirect_uris, public, token, tenant, created_at, requirements_hash, logo)

types.name: Comment
types.description:
Comments represent the comments of a user on a specific data item
tart are identified by the unique combination of `identifier` and `object`.
E.g a comment for an Image on the Mikro services would be serverd as
`@mikro/image:imageID`.

Comments always belong to the user that created it. Comments in threads
get a parent attribute set, that points to the immediate parent.

Each comment contains multiple descendents, that make up a *rich* representation
of the underlying comment data including potential mentions, or links, or
paragraphs.

fields.name: children
fields.description: The children of this comment

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The time this comment got created

fields.name: descendants
fields.description: The immediate descendends of the comments. Think typed Rich Representation

fields.name: identifier
fields.description: The identifier of the object. Consult the documentation for the format

fields.name: mentions
fields.description: The users that got mentioned in this comment

fields.name: object
fields.description: The object id of the object, on its associated service

fields.name: parent
fields.description: The parent of this comment. Think Thread

fields.name: resolvedBy
fields.description: The user that resolved this comment

fields.name: user
fields.description: The user that created this comment

types.name: Communication
types.description: A Communication

fields.name: fitsActiveOrganization
fields.description: Are we acting in the active organization of the user?

fields.name: organization
fields.description: The organization that is associated with this app

fields.name: roles
fields.description: The roles that the user has in the organization

fields.name: scope
fields.description: The scope of the app within in the organization

fields.name: user
fields.description: The user that is associated with this app

types.name: DateTime
types.description: Date with time (isoformat)

types.name: Descendant
types.description: A descendant of a comment. Descendend are used to render rich text in the frontend.

fields.name: unsafeChildren
fields.description: Unsafe children are not typed and fall back to json. This is a workaround if queries get too complex.

types.name: DescendantKind
types.description: The Kind of a Descendant

types.name: Fakt
types.description: The `Fakt` scalar type represents a reference to a fakt

types.name: Group
types.description:
A Group is the base unit of Role Based Access Control. A Group can have many users and many permissions. A user can have many groups. A user with a group that has a permission can perform the action that the permission allows.
Groups are propagated to the respecting subservices. Permissions are not. Each subservice has to define its own permissions and mappings to groups.

fields.name: users
fields.description: The users that are in the group

types.name: GroupFilter
types.description: __doc__

types.name: GroupProfile
types.description: A Profile of a User. A Profile can be used to display personalied information about a user.

fields.name: avatar
fields.description: The avatar of the group

fields.name: bio
fields.description: A short bio of the group

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the group

types.name: ID
types.description: The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: Identifier
types.description: The `Identifier` scalasr typsse represents a reference to a store previously created by the user n a datalayer

types.name: InstanceAlias
types.description: An alias for a service instance. This is used to provide a more user-friendly name for the instance.

fields.name: challenge
fields.description: The challenge of the alias. This is used to verify that the alias is reachable. If set, the alias will be accessed via the challenge URL (e.g. 'example.com/.well-known/challenge'). If not set, the alias will be accessed via the instance's URL.

fields.name: host
fields.description: The host of the alias, if its a ABSOLUTE alias (e.g. 'example.com'). If not set, the alias is relative to the layer's domain.

fields.name: instance
fields.description: The instance that this alias belongs to.

fields.name: kind
fields.description: The name of the alias. This is a human readable name of the alias.

fields.name: layer
fields.description: The layer that this alias belongs to.

fields.name: path
fields.description: The path of the alias, if its a ABSOLUTE alias (e.g. 'example.com/path'). If not set, the alias is relative to the layer's path.

fields.name: port
fields.description: The port of the alias, if its a ABSOLUTE alias (e.g. 'example.com:8080'). If not set, the alias is relative to the layer's port.

fields.name: ssl
fields.description: Is this alias using SSL? If true, the alias will be accessed via https:// instead of http://. This is used to indicate that the alias is secure and should be accessed via SSL

types.name: Int
types.description: The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31) and 2^31 - 1.

types.name: Layer
types.description: A Service is a Webservice that a Client might want to access. It is not the configured instance of the service, but the service itself.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the service. This should be a human readable description of the service.

fields.name: identifier
fields.description: The identifier of the service. This should be a globally unique string that identifies the service. We encourage you to use the reverse domain name notation. E.g. `com.example.myservice`

fields.name: instances
fields.description: The instances of the service. A service instance is a configured instance of a service. It will be configured by a configuration backend and will be used to send to the client as a configuration. It should never contain sensitive information.

fields.name: logo
fields.description: The logo of the service. This should be a url to a logo that can be used to represent the service.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the layer

types.name: LayerFilter
types.description: Layer(id, name, identifier, logo, description, dns_probe, get_probe, kind)

types.name: LeafDescendant
types.description: A leaf of text. This is the most basic descendant and always ends a tree.

fields.name: unsafeChildren
fields.description: Unsafe children are not typed and fall back to json. This is a workaround if queries get too complex.

types.name: MediaStore
types.description: MediaStore(id, path, key, bucket, populated, s3store_ptr)

fields.name: path
fields.description: The stodre of the image

types.name: Membership
types.description: A Membership is a relation between a User and an Organization. It can have multiple Roles assigned to it.

fields.name: groups
fields.description: The groups that the user has in the organization

fields.name: roles
fields.description: The roles that the user has in the organization

types.name: MembershipFilter
types.description: __doc__

types.name: MentionDescendant
types.description: A mention of a user

fields.name: unsafeChildren
fields.description: Unsafe children are not typed and fall back to json. This is a workaround if queries get too complex.

fields.name: addItemsToStash
fields.description: Add items to a stash

fields.name: createStash
fields.description: Create a new stash

fields.name: deleteStashItems
fields.description: Delete items from a stash

fields.name: updateStash
fields.description: Update a stash

types.name: Oauth2Client
types.description: OAuth2Client(id, user, organization, client_id, client_secret, redirect_uris, scope, token_endpoint_auth_method, grant_types, response_types)

types.name: Organization
types.description: An Organization is a group of users that can work together on a project.

fields.name: activeUsers
fields.description: The users that are currently active in the organization

fields.name: description
fields.description: A short description of the organization

fields.name: logo
fields.description: The logo of the organization

fields.name: roles
fields.description: The roles that are available in the organization

fields.name: users
fields.description: The users that are part of the organization

types.name: ParagraphDescendant
types.description: A Paragraph of text

fields.name: unsafeChildren
fields.description: Unsafe children are not typed and fall back to json. This is a workaround if queries get too complex.

types.name: PresignedPostCredentials
types.description: Temporary Credentials for a file upload that can be used by a Client (e.g. in a python datalayer)

types.name: Profile
types.description: A Profile of a User. A Profile can be used to display personalied information about a user.

fields.name: avatar
fields.description: The avatar of the user

fields.name: bio
fields.description: A short bio of the user

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the user

types.name: RedeemToken
types.description:
A redeem token is a token that can be used to redeem the rights to create
a client. It is used to give the recipient the right to create a client.

If the token is not redeemed within the expires_at time, it will be invalid.
If the token has been redeemed, but the manifest has changed, the token will be invalid.

fields.name: client
fields.description: The client that this redeem token belongs to.

fields.name: token
fields.description: The token of the redeem token

fields.name: user
fields.description: The user that this redeem token belongs to.

types.name: RedeemTokenFilter
types.description:
A redeem token is a token that can be used to redeem the rights to create
a client. It is used to give the recipient the right to create a client.

If the token is not redeemed within the expires_at time, it will be invalid.
If the token has been redeemed, but the manifest has changed, the token will be invalid.

types.name: Release
types.description: A Release is a version of an app. Releases might change over time. E.g. a release might be updated to fix a bug, and the release might be updated to add a new feature. This is why they are the home for `scopes` and `requirements`, which might change over the release cycle.

fields.name: app
fields.description: The app that this release belongs to.

fields.name: clients
fields.description: The clients of the release

fields.name: logo
fields.description: The logo of the release. This should be a url to a logo that can be used to represent the release.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the release. This should be a string that identifies the release beyond the version number. E.g. `canary`.

fields.name: requirements
fields.description: The requirements of the release. Requirements are used to limit the access of a client to a user's data. They represent app-level permissions.

fields.name: scopes
fields.description: The scopes of the release. Scopes are used to limit the access of a client to a user's data. They represent app-level permissions.

fields.name: version
fields.description: The version of the release. This should be a string that identifies the version of the release. We enforce semantic versioning notation. E.g. `0.1.0`. The version is unique per app.

types.name: Role
types.description: A Role is a set of permissions that can be assigned to a user. It is used to define what a user can do in the system.

types.name: RoleFilter
types.description: __doc__

types.name: Scope
types.description: A scope that can be assigned to a client. Scopes are used to limit the access of a client to a user's data. They represent app-level permissions.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the scope. This is a human readable description of the scope.

fields.name: label
fields.description: The label of the scope. This is the human readable name of the scope.

fields.name: value
fields.description: The value of the scope. This is the value that is used in the OAuth2 flow.

types.name: Service
types.description: A Service is a Webservice that a Client might want to access. It is not the configured instance of the service, but the service itself.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the service. This should be a human readable description of the service.

fields.name: identifier
fields.description: The identifier of the service. This should be a globally unique string that identifies the service. We encourage you to use the reverse domain name notation. E.g. `com.example.myservice`

fields.name: instances
fields.description: The instances of the service. A service instance is a configured instance of a service. It will be configured by a configuration backend and will be used to send to the client as a configuration. It should never contain sensitive information.

fields.name: logo
fields.description: The logo of the app. This should be a url to a logo that can be used to represent the app.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the service

types.name: ServiceFilter
types.description: Service(id, name, identifier, logo, description)

types.name: ServiceIdentifier
types.description: The Service identifier is a unique identifier for a service. It is used to identify the service in the database and in the code. We encourage you to use the reverse domain name notation. E.g. `com.example.myservice`

types.name: ServiceInstance
types.description: A ServiceInstance is a configured instance of a Service. It will be configured by a configuration backend and will be used to send to the client as a configuration. It should never contain sensitive information.

fields.name: aliases
fields.description: The aliases of the instance. An alias is a way to reach the instance. Clients can use these aliases to check if they can reach the instance. An alias can be an absolute alias (e.g. 'example.com') or a relative alias (e.g. 'example.com/path'). If the alias is relative, it will be relative to the layer's domain, port and path.

fields.name: allowedGroups
fields.description: The groups that are allowed to use this instance.

fields.name: allowedUsers
fields.description: The users that are allowed to use this instance.

fields.name: deniedGroups
fields.description: The groups that are denied to use this instance.

fields.name: deniedUsers
fields.description: The users that are denied to use this instance.

fields.name: identifier
fields.description: The identifier of the instance. This is a unique string that identifies the instance. It is used to identify the instance in the code and in the database.

fields.name: logo
fields.description: The logo of the app. This should be a url to a logo that can be used to represent the app.

fields.name: mappings
fields.description: The mappings of the composition. A mapping is a mapping of a service to a service instance. This is used to configure the composition.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the instance. This is a human readable name of the instance.

fields.name: service
fields.description: The service that this instance belongs to.

types.name: ServiceInstanceFilter
types.description: ServiceInstance(id, service, logo, identifier, steward, template)

types.name: ServiceInstanceMapping
types.description: A ServiceInstance is a configured instance of a Service. It will be configured by a configuration backend and will be used to send to the client as a configuration. It should never contain sensitive information.

fields.name: client
fields.description: The client that this instance belongs to.

fields.name: instance
fields.description: The service that this instance belongs to.

fields.name: key
fields.description: The key of the instance. This is a unique string that identifies the instance. It is used to identify the instance in the code and in the database.

fields.name: optional
fields.description: Is this mapping optional? If a mapping is optional, you can configure the client without this mapping.

types.name: Stash
types.description: A Stash

fields.name: owner
fields.description: The number of items in the stash

types.name: StashFilter
types.description: __doc__

types.name: StashItem
types.description: A stashed item

types.name: StashItemFilter
types.description: StashItem(id, stash, identifier, object, added_by, added_at, updated_at)

types.name: String
types.description: The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: SystemMessage
types.description:
A System Message is a message that is sent to a user. 
It can be used to notify the user of important events or to request their attention.
System messages can use Rekuest Hooks as actions to allow the user to interact with the message.

fields.name: action
fields.description: The action to take (e.g. the node)

types.name: UnsafeChild
types.description: The `Identifier` scalasr typsse represents a reference to a store previously created by the user n a datalayer

types.name: User
types.description:
A User is a person that can log in to the system. They are uniquely identified by their username.
And can have an email address associated with them (but don't have to).

A user can be assigned to groups and has a profile that can be used to display information about them.
Detail information about a user can be found in the profile.

All users can have social accounts associated with them. These are used to authenticate the user with external services,
such as ORCID or GitHub.

fields.name: groups
fields.description: The groups this user belongs to. A user will get all permissions granted to each of their groups.

fields.name: memberships
fields.description: The memberships of the user in organizations

fields.name: username
fields.description: Required. 150 characters or fewer. Letters, digits and @/./+/-/_ only.

types.name: UserFilter
types.description:
A User of the System

Lok Users are the main users of the system. They can be assigned to groups and have profiles, that can be used to display information about them.
Each user is identifier by a unique username, and can have an email address associated with them.

inputFields.name: username
inputFields.description: Required. 150 characters or fewer. Letters, digits and @/./+/-/_ only.

types.name: Version
types.description: The `Version` represents a semver version string

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name, description and optional `specifiedByURL`, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields`, `interfaces`, and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted using the Markdown syntax, as specified by [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org/).

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

directives.name: specifiedBy
directives.description: Exposes a URL that specifies the behavior of this scalar.

args.name: url
args.description: The URL that specifies the behavior of this scalar.
